text: In this experiment, the height of the sphere, cone, and cylinder are the same. The diameter of sphere is the same as the diameter of the base of the cylinder and cone.

Experiment

Make a Prediction

  • What is the relationship between a cylinder, cone, and sphere with the same diameters?

Conduct the Experiments

Equipment

  • Equipment
  • Modeling clay
  • Transparent plastic, about Â½ sheet
  • Paper
  • Tape
  • Filling substance, such as sand, bird seed, rice, rice cereal

Directions for Making the Sphere and the Cylinder (individual, partner, or small group)

  • Make a sphere from modeling clay.
  • Measure its diameter.
  • Make a cylinder with an open top and bottom from the transparent plastic. Fit the cylinder snugly around the sphere. We want the diameter of the cylinder and sphere to be equal.
  • Trim the cylinder. We want its height is equal to the vertical diameter of the sphere.
  • Tape the sides of the cylinder together so it remains rigid.

Directions for Finding the Volume of the Sphere

  • Flatten the clay sphere so that the clay fits snugly in the bottom of the cylinder.
  • Mark the height of the flattened sphere on the cylinder.
  • Measure and record the cylinder height, cylinder radius, empty space height, and flattened sphere height.

Directions for Making the Cone

  • Take the clay out of the cylinder.
  • Roll a piece of stiff paper into a cone shape so that the tip touches the bottom and does not have a hole at the point.
  • Tape the cone shape along the seam.
  • Trim the cone so it is the same height (and radius) as the cylinder.

Directions for Finding the Volume of the Cone

  • Fill the cone to the top with the filling substance.
  • Empty the contents into the cylinder.
  • Repeat this as many times as needed to fill the cylinder completely.
  • Keep track of the number of cones needed.

Analyze the Data

  • What is the relationship between the volumes of the sphere and the cylinder?

When you gently flatten the clay sphere in the cylinder, the height of the transformed clay is about 2/3 of the height of the cylinder. It means that the volume of sphere is 2/3 of the volume of cylinder.
• What is the relationship between the volumes of the cone and the cylinder?

When you fill rice or sand in the cone and pour into the cylinder, it will fill up 1/3 height of the cylinder. Or, you can repeat pouring rice or sand until you find that you can fill up the cylinder with three cones. It means that the volume of the cone is 1/3 of the volume of cylinder. Or, the volume of the cylinder is three times greater than the volume of the cone.
